review: It took about 45 minutes and several tries to get it to connect to our home wireless network.  The change I'd made was to take the USB power for the Chromecast from the Television set instead of a wall outlet.  Once set up, it has worked as advertised.  It also has beautiful background photographs if no signal is being sent to it.

author: Frank A. Terry Jr.

review: Chromecast works great with compatible websites like Netflix and YouTube (you have to add the Netflix app to your Chrome homepage).  It doesn't work so well when watching video from different websites, such as pbs.org.  The video is jerky and hard to watch.  I tried closing all other open tabs and programs, but nothing really worked to improve the video quality.  Since I mostly use Chromecast to watch Netflix, this isn't often an issue for me.  Netflix is a clear, beautiful video and I like that I can close my laptop while the video keeps playing.  Or, I can multi-task and browse the web while the video plays.  The quality of audio and video is much better than when using an HDMI cord from my laptop to my TV.  Plus, it's not bulky and inconvenient like the cord is.Something else I learned is that sometimes I have my Netflix page "casted" to the Chromecast, but the video plays on my computer, not my TV.  I learned that sometimes I have to "cast" the video itself to the Chromecast, not just the web page.  (There's an option for "casting" on Netflix and YouTube videos).Overall, I'm glad I bought Chromecast.  It makes watching Netflix a pleasure!
author: C. Lynne "booklover"

review: Small, straight-forward, simple, and superior. Much easier and better than my boyfriend's $150 wireless receptor. My only notes of complaint are that they haven't developed an Amazon app (to play movies from my Prime account) and that Google hasn't developed tabcasting for tablets yet.
